newsitem.title: LESOTHO: Lesotho's Prime Minister forms breakaway party.
newsitem.headline: Lesotho's Prime Minister forms breakaway party.

text.p: Lesotho's Prime Minister Ntsu Mokhehle and several senior cabinet members formed a new breakaway political movement at the weekend, ending months of tensions over leadership within the Basotholand Congress Party.
Mokhehle was on Saturday unanimously voted leader of the new Lesotho Congress for Democracy Party by about 1,000 people in the capital Maseru.

Mokhehle was ousted as leader of the Basotholand Congress Party (BCP) earlier this year at a conference called by a rival faction within the party after accusations the tiny kingdom was drifting into lawlessness.
A Lesotho High Court judge however later reinstated the besieged premier and ordered the BCP to call another meeting to elect a new leader, scheduled for July.
On Friday, BCP executive members, hearing of plans by Mokhehle to call a meeting on Saturday, said he was trying to remove them from office.

But in a surprise move Mokhehle, backed by several senior government officials including Foreign Minister Kelebone Maope, Law and Constitutional Affairs Minister Sephiri Motanyane and Information Minister Monyane Moleleki, announced a new party.

The new movement's flag retains the colours of the BCP -- black, green and red -- but in reverse, with an insignia of a black eagle across the flag. Mokhehle's first name in the Sotho language means "eagle".
Radio Lesotho said the premier will address a news conference on Monday in which he will give details of the new party.
